As shown below, such a cancellation, and the unitarity of the theory, are automatically implemented in the GM model.


 

\section{The first possibility: the 2HDM}\label{sec:2HDM}

 
 The first possibility considered in the introduction section is the simplest: perturbative unitarity is maintained by having the scalar resonance coupling at a special value fixed  by gauge invariance (see {eq.~(\ref{{eq:2hdm}})}). 
 
 This would be the first choice in trying to incorporate the resonance within a model. Unfortunately, the parameters of the 2HDM model must be pushed to  rather unrealistic values in order to accomodate the di-photon data~\cite{Altmannshofer:2015xfo}. These values are particularly worrisome in the light of the required size of the  the Yukawa couplings, the renormalized values of which  bring the theory into a non-perturbative regime~\cite{Son:2015vfl}. 
 
 We therefore consider the other case discussed in section I.
 
 
 

\section{The GM model}

The GM model contains a complex $SU(2)_L$ doublet field $\phi$ ($Y = 1$), a real 
triplet field $\xi$ ($Y = 0$), and a complex  $SU(2)_L$ triplet field $\chi$ ($Y = 2$).
The scalar content of the theory can be organised 
in terms of the $SU(2)_L \otimes SU(2)_R$ symmetry, and we define the following multiplets
\begin{eqnarray}\label{eq:GMScalars}
\Phi_{ (\textbf{2},\textbf{2})} &\equiv&
\left(
\begin{array}{cc}
\phi^{0*}  & \phi^+     \\
 \phi^- & \phi^0      
\end{array}
\right), \\
\quad \Delta_{ (\textbf{3},\textbf{3})}&\equiv& 
\left(
\begin{array}{ccc}
 \chi^{0*} & \xi^+  & \chi^{++}   \\
 \chi^- & \xi^0  & \chi^+  \\
 \chi^{--} & \xi^{-}  & \chi^0   
\end{array}
\right),
\end{eqnarray}
whose VEVs are
prevtext:
with the same sign as the Higgs boson, while
 \begin{eqnarray}
 a(s,t)|_{H_5} & =&   -\frac{g_{H_5}^2}{v^2} \left[  \frac{t^2}{t-m_{H_5}^2} \right.  {\nonumber} \\
 & & \left. + \frac{u^2}{u-m_{H_5}^2} - \frac{2}{3} \frac{s^2}{s-m_{H_5}^2} \right] 
 \label{eq:tree5}\, ,
 \end{eqnarray}
gives a (repulsive) negative contribution. 

Considering the limit $s \gg m_W^2, m_{H_1}, m_{H_1}' m_{H_5}$---and having the Higgs boson contribution already cancel the contribution  from the vector bosons to the coefficient $B$ in {eq.~(\ref{{eq:unitarity}})}---an exact cancellation between eq.~(\ref{eq:tree1}) and eq.~(\ref{eq:tree5}) requires

nexttext:
with
$v_\phi^2 + 8 v_\Delta^2 = v^2 = 1/\sqrt{2}\,  G_F \simeq (246 \, \mbox{GeV})^2$.   The VEVs of the two triplets must be the same in order to preserve custodial $SU(2)_C$.

The doublet and the two triplet states can be written in components:
\begin{eqnarray}
\phi &=&
\left(
\begin{array}{c}
   \phi^+  \\
 (v_{\phi} + \phi^0_{r} + \imath \phi^0_{i})/\sqrt{2}   
\end{array}
\right)~,
 \\
\xi &=&
\left(
\begin{array}{c}
 \xi^+   \\
 v_{\Delta} + \xi^0    \\
  \xi^-
\end{array}
\right)~, \\
\chi &=&
\left(
\begin{array}{c}
  \chi^{++}   \\
  \chi^+   \\
  v_{\Delta} + ( \chi^0_{r} + \imath \chi^0_{i})/\sqrt{2}  
\end{array}
\right)~,
\end{eqnarray}
with $\phi^- = -(\phi^+)^*$, $\xi^- = -(\xi^+)^*$, $\chi^- = -(\chi^+)^*$.

The most general potential that conserves  $SU(2)_C$ is given by
\begin{eqnarray}\label{eq:Potential}
V(\Phi, \Delta) & =& \frac{\mu_2^2} {\mbox{Tr}\,} \Phi^\dag \Phi + \frac{\mu_3^2}{2} {\mbox{Tr}\,} \Delta^\dag \Delta  {\nonumber} \\
& & + \lambda_1 \left[  {\mbox{Tr}\,} \Phi^\dag \Phi \right]^2 + \lambda_2  {\mbox{Tr}\,} \Phi^\dag \Phi \, {\mbox{Tr}\,} \Delta^\dag \Delta {\nonumber} \\
& & + \lambda_3 {\mbox{Tr}\,} \Delta^\dag \Delta \Delta^\dag \Delta +   \lambda_4 \left[{\mbox{Tr}\,} \Delta^\dag \Delta \right]^2  {\nonumber}\\
& & - \lambda_5 {\mbox{Tr}\,} \left( \Phi^\dag \sigma^a \Phi \sigma^b  \right) \, {\mbox{Tr}\,}  \left(\Delta^\dag t^2 \Delta t^b \right) {\nonumber} \\
& &  - M_1  {\mbox{Tr}\,} \left( \Phi^\dag \tau^a \Phi \tau^b \right) (U \Delta U^\dag)_{ab}{\nonumber}  \\
& & - M_2 {\mbox{Tr}\,} \left( \Delta^\dag t^a \Delta t^b \right) (U \Delta U^\dag)_{ab} \, ,
\end{eqnarray} 
where $\tau$ and $t$ are the $SU(2)$ generators in the doublet and triplet representation respectively, and $U$ a matrix that rotates $\Delta$ into the Cartesian basis.

From the (canonically normalised) kinetic terms
prevtext:
As shown below, such a cancellation, and the unitarity of the theory, are automatically implemented in the GM model.


 

\section{The first possibility: the 2HDM}\label{sec:2HDM}

 
 The first possibility considered in the introduction section is the simplest: perturbative unitarity is maintained by having the scalar resonance coupling at a special value fixed  by gauge invariance (see {eq.~(\ref{{eq:2hdm}})}). 
 
 This would be the first choice in trying to incorporate the resonance within a model. Unfortunately, the parameters of the 2HDM model must be pushed to  rather unrealistic values in order to accomodate the di-photon data~\cite{Altmannshofer:2015xfo}. These values are particularly worrisome in the light of the required size of the  the Yukawa couplings, the renormalized values of which  bring the theory into a non-perturbative regime~\cite{Son:2015vfl}. 
 
 We therefore consider the other case discussed in section I.
 
 
 

\section{The GM model}

The GM model contains a complex $SU(2)_L$ doublet field $\phi$ ($Y = 1$), a real 
triplet field $\xi$ ($Y = 0$), and a complex  $SU(2)_L$ triplet field $\chi$ ($Y = 2$).
The scalar content of the theory can be organised 
in terms of the $SU(2)_L \otimes SU(2)_R$ symmetry, and we define the following multiplets
\begin{eqnarray}\label{eq:GMScalars}
\Phi_{ (\textbf{2},\textbf{2})} &\equiv&
\left(
\begin{array}{cc}
\phi^{0*}  & \phi^+     \\
 \phi^- & \phi^0      
\end{array}
\right), \\
\quad \Delta_{ (\textbf{3},\textbf{3})}&\equiv& 
\left(
\begin{array}{ccc}
 \chi^{0*} & \xi^+  & \chi^{++}   \\
 \chi^- & \xi^0  & \chi^+  \\
 \chi^{--} & \xi^{-}  & \chi^0   
\end{array}
\right),
\end{eqnarray}
whose VEVs are

and}\quad\langle\Delta\rangle=\frac{v_{\Delta}}{\sqrt{2}}\,\hat{I}_{3\times 3}\,," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mfrac><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>ϕ</mi></msub><msqrt><mn>2</mn></msqrt></mfrac></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>I</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mtext>and</mtext></mrow></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mfrac><msub><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi></msub><msqrt><mn>2</mn></msqrt></mfrac></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>I</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mpadded></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
we can read the interactions with the EW gauge bosons. 
Considering the neutral components of the scalar fields in eq.~(\ref{eq:GMScalars}),
a direct computation gives
\begin{eqnarray}\label{eq:Basic}
\mathcal{L}_{\rm kin} &\supset&
(v_{\phi} + \phi^0_{r})^2\left(
\frac{g^2}{4}W_{\mu}^+W^{-,\mu} + \frac{g^2 + g^{\prime\,2}}{8}Z_{\mu}Z^{\mu}
\right)\nonumber \\
&+& (v_{\Delta} + \xi^0)^2
\left(
g^2 W_{\mu}^+W^{-,\mu} 
\right) \\
&+& 
(\sqrt{2}\, v_{\Delta} + \chi^0_{r})^2\left(
\frac{g^2}{2}W_{\mu}^+W^{-,\mu} + \frac{g^2 + g^{\prime\,2}}{2}Z_{\mu}Z^{\mu} {\nonumber}
\right)\,.
\end{eqnarray}
The imaginary part of $\phi$ and $\chi$ does not interact with the EW gauge bosons as a consequence of $CP$ invariance.
The gauge boson masses are  given by
prevtext:
with
$v_\phi^2 + 8 v_\Delta^2 = v^2 = 1/\sqrt{2}\,  G_F \simeq (246 \, \mbox{GeV})^2$.   The VEVs of the two triplets must be the same in order to preserve custodial $SU(2)_C$.

The doublet and the two triplet states can be written in components:
\begin{eqnarray}
\phi &=&
\left(
\begin{array}{c}
   \phi^+  \\
 (v_{\phi} + \phi^0_{r} + \imath \phi^0_{i})/\sqrt{2}   
\end{array}
\right)~,
 \\
\xi &=&
\left(
\begin{array}{c}
 \xi^+   \\
 v_{\Delta} + \xi^0    \\
  \xi^-
\end{array}
\right)~, \\
\chi &=&
\left(
\begin{array}{c}
  \chi^{++}   \\
  \chi^+   \\
  v_{\Delta} + ( \chi^0_{r} + \imath \chi^0_{i})/\sqrt{2}  
\end{array}
\right)~,
\end{eqnarray}
with $\phi^- = -(\phi^+)^*$, $\xi^- = -(\xi^+)^*$, $\chi^- = -(\chi^+)^*$.

The most general potential that conserves  $SU(2)_C$ is given by
\begin{eqnarray}\label{eq:Potential}
V(\Phi, \Delta) & =& \frac{\mu_2^2} {\mbox{Tr}\,} \Phi^\dag \Phi + \frac{\mu_3^2}{2} {\mbox{Tr}\,} \Delta^\dag \Delta  {\nonumber} \\
& & + \lambda_1 \left[  {\mbox{Tr}\,} \Phi^\dag \Phi \right]^2 + \lambda_2  {\mbox{Tr}\,} \Phi^\dag \Phi \, {\mbox{Tr}\,} \Delta^\dag \Delta {\nonumber} \\
& & + \lambda_3 {\mbox{Tr}\,} \Delta^\dag \Delta \Delta^\dag \Delta +   \lambda_4 \left[{\mbox{Tr}\,} \Delta^\dag \Delta \right]^2  {\nonumber}\\
& & - \lambda_5 {\mbox{Tr}\,} \left( \Phi^\dag \sigma^a \Phi \sigma^b  \right) \, {\mbox{Tr}\,}  \left(\Delta^\dag t^2 \Delta t^b \right) {\nonumber} \\
& &  - M_1  {\mbox{Tr}\,} \left( \Phi^\dag \tau^a \Phi \tau^b \right) (U \Delta U^\dag)_{ab}{\nonumber}  \\
& & - M_2 {\mbox{Tr}\,} \left( \Delta^\dag t^a \Delta t^b \right) (U \Delta U^\dag)_{ab} \, ,
\end{eqnarray} 
where $\tau$ and $t$ are the $SU(2)$ generators in the doublet and triplet representation respectively, and $U$ a matrix that rotates $\Delta$ into the Cartesian basis.

From the (canonically normalised) kinetic terms

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\mathcal{L}_{\rm kin}=|D^{(\phi)}_{\mu}\phi|^{2}+\frac{1}{2}|D^{(\xi)}_{\mu}%
\xi|^{2}+|D^{(\chi)}_{\mu}\chi|^{2}\,," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi><mi>kin</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>D</mi><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ϕ</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>D</mi><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ξ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ξ</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>D</mi><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>χ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>χ</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mpadded></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Under $SU(2)_C$ we have the group representations
$(\textbf{2},\textbf{2}) \sim \textbf{1} \oplus \textbf{3}$, and $(\textbf{3},\textbf{3}) \sim \textbf{1} \oplus \textbf{3} \oplus \textbf{5}$.
One of the two triplets is unphysical, since it represents the Goldstone bosons eaten by the EW gauge bosons. 
Accordingly, the GM model has ten physical degrees of freedom: 
two $SU(2)_C$ singlets $H_1^0$, $H_1^{0^{\prime}}$ (the Higgs and the additional scalar resonance), one $SU(2)_C$ triplet $(H_3^+, H_3^0, H_3^-)$ and 
one $SU(2)_C$ quintuplet $(H_5^{++}, H_5^+, H_5^0, H_5^-, H_5^{--})$.

If compared with the setup envisaged in section~\ref{eq:SectionI}, 
the spectrum of the GM model has one additional scalar triplet.
However, the triplet $H_3$ does not interact with the EW gauge bosons.

The mass eigenstates in terms of gauge eigenstates are
\begin{eqnarray}
H_5^{++} &=& \chi^{++}~,{\nonumber} \\
H_5^{+} &=& (\chi^+ - \xi^+)/\sqrt{2}~,\nonumber\\
H_5^{0} &=&  (2\xi^0 - \sqrt{2}\chi^0_{r} )/\sqrt{6}~,\nonumber\\
H_3^+ &=& \cos\theta_H(\chi^+ + \xi^+)/\sqrt{2} - \sin\theta_H\phi^+,\nonumber\\
H_3^0 &=& \imath (-\cos\theta_H \chi^0_{i} + \sin\theta_H\phi^0_{i})\, ,\nonumber\\
H_1^0 &=& \phi^0_{r}~,\nonumber\\
H_1^{0^{\prime}} &=& (\sqrt{2} \chi^0_{r} + \xi^0)/\sqrt{3}~.
\end{eqnarray}

From the Lagrangian in eq.~(\ref{eq:Basic}) we find the physical couplings
\begin{eqnarray}\label{eq:Canc1}
\mathcal{L}_{\rm kin} &\supset& \cos\theta_H\frac{H_1^0}{v}\left(
2m_W^2W_{\mu}^+W^{-,\mu} + m_Z^2 Z_{\mu}Z^{\mu}
\right)\\
&+& \frac{2\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{3}}\sin\theta_H 
\frac{H_1^{0^{\prime}}}{v}
\left(
2m_W^2W_{\mu}^+W^{-,\mu} + m_Z^2 Z_{\mu}Z^{\mu}
\right)\nonumber \\
&+& \frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}\sin\theta_H \frac{H_5^{0}}{v}\left(
m_W^2W_{\mu}^+W^{-,\mu} - m_Z^2 Z_{\mu}Z^{\mu}
\right)~,\nonumber
\end{eqnarray}
where
the doublet-triplet mixing angle is given by
prevtext:
we can read the interactions with the EW gauge bosons. 
Considering the neutral components of the scalar fields in eq.~(\ref{eq:GMScalars}),
a direct computation gives
\begin{eqnarray}\label{eq:Basic}

(v_{\phi} + \phi^0_{r})^2\left(

\right)\nonumber \\
&+& (v_{\Delta} + \xi^0)^2
\left(
g^2 W_{\mu}^+W^{-,\mu} 
\right) \\
&+& 
(\sqrt{2}\, v_{\Delta} + \chi^0_{r})^2\left(
\frac{g^2}{2}W_{\mu}^+W^{-,\mu} + \frac{g^2 + g^{\prime\,2}}{2}Z_{\mu}Z^{\mu} {\nonumber}
\right)\,.
\end{eqnarray}
The imaginary part of $\phi$ and $\chi$ does not interact with the EW gauge bosons as a consequence of $CP$ invariance.

prevtext:
Under $SU(2)_C$ we have the group representations
$(\textbf{2},\textbf{2}) \sim \textbf{1} \oplus \textbf{3}$, and $(\textbf{3},\textbf{3}) \sim \textbf{1} \oplus \textbf{3} \oplus \textbf{5}$.
One of the two triplets is unphysical, since it represents the Goldstone bosons eaten by the EW gauge bosons. 
Accordingly, the GM model has ten physical degrees of freedom: 
two $SU(2)_C$ singlets $H_1^0$, $H_1^{0^{\prime}}$ (the Higgs and the additional scalar resonance), one $SU(2)_C$ triplet $(H_3^+, H_3^0, H_3^-)$ and 
one $SU(2)_C$ quintuplet $(H_5^{++}, H_5^+, H_5^0, H_5^-, H_5^{--})$.

If compared with the setup envisaged in section~\ref{eq:SectionI}, 
the spectrum of the GM model has one additional scalar triplet.
However, the triplet $H_3$ does not interact with the EW gauge bosons.

The mass eigenstates in terms of gauge eigenstates are
\begin{eqnarray}
H_5^{++} &=& \chi^{++}~,{\nonumber} \\
H_5^{+} &=& (\chi^+ - \xi^+)/\sqrt{2}~,\nonumber\\
H_5^{0} &=&  (2\xi^0 - \sqrt{2}\chi^0_{r} )/\sqrt{6}~,\nonumber\\
H_3^+ &=& \cos\theta_H(\chi^+ + \xi^+)/\sqrt{2} - \sin\theta_H\phi^+,\nonumber\\
H_3^0 &=& \imath (-\cos\theta_H \chi^0_{i} + \sin\theta_H\phi^0_{i})\, ,\nonumber\\
H_1^0 &=& \phi^0_{r}~,\nonumber\\
H_1^{0^{\prime}} &=& (\sqrt{2} \chi^0_{r} + \xi^0)/\sqrt{3}~.
\end{eqnarray}

From the Lagrangian in eq.~(\ref{eq:Basic}) we find the physical couplings
\begin{eqnarray}\label{eq:Canc1}
\mathcal{L}_{\rm kin} &\supset& \cos\theta_H\frac{H_1^0}{v}\left(
2m_W^2W_{\mu}^+W^{-,\mu} + m_Z^2 Z_{\mu}Z^{\mu}
\right)\\
&+& \frac{2\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{3}}\sin\theta_H 
\frac{H_1^{0^{\prime}}}{v}
\left(
2m_W^2W_{\mu}^+W^{-,\mu} + m_Z^2 Z_{\mu}Z^{\mu}
\right)\nonumber \\
&+& \frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}\sin\theta_H \frac{H_5^{0}}{v}\left(
m_W^2W_{\mu}^+W^{-,\mu} - m_Z^2 Z_{\mu}Z^{\mu}
\right)~,\nonumber
\end{eqnarray}
where
the doublet-triplet mixing angle is given by
